results.title: The Promised land
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, BBC and Time Inc
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American visions”.
In the second program of the series, Robert Hughes explores how religion was to have a fundamental impact on the shaping of American culture. The first European settlers presented the New World as both paradise and hell, a source of plunder, and a center of religious fantasy. During the early years of what Hughes describes as an invasion of North America by Europeans, the Spaniards conquered New Mexican Indian pueblos and citadels such as Acoma and set up their own architectural forms. These came to include the adobe Catholic church and the art of the santos- crude and vivid and designed to drive out the ancient gods from Indian minds. Meanwhile, seventeenth-century New England began to create a severe culture of practicality and moral rigor produced by Puritanism and later Utopian sects such as the Shakers. Then the Germans came, the Pennsylvania Dutch, the Quakers. In an America conceived as a religious refuge, a sanctuary for what Abraham Lincoln called the “half-chosen people,” what was used bears the print of what was believed. This pervaded the early paintings, crafts and buildings of Puritan America. The program concludes with the emergence of a culture which could begin to be called American. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Republic of virtue
results.creator_credit: James Kent, BBC and Time Inc
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “American visions”.
In this first program of the series, Robert Hughes announces his intention to look at America through the lens of its visual culture and to see what we can tell about the American experience through the things Americans have made. The program charts the foundation of American identity following the War of Independence and ends on the eve of the American Civil War. The dominance of neo-classicism as a style which would imbue the nation with age-old values came to rule the aesthetics behind the building of Washington, D. C. America’s first major architect, Thomas Jefferson, is profiled with sequences at his home in Monticello and The University of Virginia, both of which he designed. The capital’s monuments to George Washington and Lincoln echo the need for authority, carried through in minimalist form today by the Vietnam Memorial designed by Maya Lin. The work of the nation’s first major painters; Benjamin West, John Singleton Copley, and Charles Willson Peale is outlined and the paintings in the Capitol Building are described. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.brief_description: Andrew Graham-Dixon examines British art- its lost medieval legacy, and why it developed differently to the European mainstream.

results.title: Our house
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode six of ‘A History of British art’ looks at the movement of modernism - Dada, Surrealism and Expressionism, and the misconception that the movement passed British art by. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: All change
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “A History of British art”.
Having invented modern painting, the British turned their backs on it. The vigour of 19th century engineering is contrasted with the moralising character of its arts, and its need to smother the radical energies of the nation. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Modern art
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode four of ‘A History of British art’ shows that what is commonly thought of as modern painting began with Constable and Turner in England, where for the first time the artist insisted on his own version as the guiding principle. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

group_siblings.title: My wife, my horse and myself

results.title: My wife, my horse and myself
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “A History of British art”.
The traditional 18th century style, portraits of dogs, horses and family was the province of British artists; their aristocratic clients bought their ‘real art’ in Italy. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: North and south
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode two of ‘A History of British art’ looks at the brilliant, mad excessiveness of the Elizabethan visual imagination, in architecture, painting, gardening and language. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Dreams and hammers
results.creator_credit: Paul Tickell, Tanya Seghatchian and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode one of ‘A History of British art’ looks at two extraordinary, forgotten legacies at the heart of the British art tradition: the lost tradition of Catholic medieval art, and the tradition of post-Reformation iconoclasm- an entire culture that was devoted to destroying art. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.
